text: My hair is a disaster.

It looks like I just woke up.But you know
what?
My stylist says it's okay.
Not better!
Let's just leave it at that.
Who need this!?

This weekend I got to chat it up with some
actors, directors and producers on the red
carpet at the Spirit Awards in LA.

Now my red carpet appearance was a little
different than what you think because I was

actually in my living room at home in Toronto,
but also on the red carpet in LA.
How does that work?
Let me tell you!

Skype, which you know I love dearly actually
contacted me to take part in this event.

At the very beginning of the red carpet at
the awards, Skype had a van set up.

Inside the van was a computer where I lived
for the afternoon.

So on that computer screen was myself and
4 other film enthusiasts.

The celebrities would be brought into the
van where we would chat with each other via
Skype.
Oh the power of Skype!
This is how the day unfolded.
Hey guys!
So, today is a very exciting day.

I am interviewing celebrities on the red carpet
for the Spirit Awards.I am just so honoured
and happy to be part of this.

I just finished setting up the set where I
am going to be enjoying the red carpet from.

We got my lights to keep it nice and bright
in here.

I've got my questions prepared for each actor
and director thats going to be coming in to
talk with me.
I'm a little nervous but mostly excited.

This is going to be really fun and different
than anything I've ever done before.

Here are some of the actors, directors, writers
that are going to be coming in to talk with
me.
I'll just give you a quick scroll through.

What tips and techniques do you have to get
that kind of performance out of so many people?
It starts with the script.

You have to find the right people and that's
more difficult.
You just know it when you see it.

Do you get nervous still in auditions or when
you're on set?
How do you deal with it?
The more you're prepared, the less your anxious.

I was so pleased to get to talk to the producer
of Blue Jasmine, Edward Walson.

The dreamy Julian Morris from Pretty Little
Liars and Once Upon a Time.

Jeff Nichols the director and writer of Mud
and Adewale from Lost.
He was so so great.
I really loved chatting with him.

He gave me some excellent advice on acting
and auditions.

I had asked him actually a couple of questions
and one was if he still got nervous when he

went into auditions and how he dealt with
that.

He told me that it took him quite some time
to figure this out, but eventually the way

he approached auditions was he went in and
he just performed as if it was the one chance

he was very going to get to play that character,
which is in a lot of the time the case.

He performs for himself and that's the reason
why he loves acting.
That's how he treats the audition.
He doesn't treat it as if he NEEDS the job.

He treats it as a performance in a role he
already has.

Another thing that really stood out to me
was how the directors and producers said how
often they use Skype for auditions.

Sometimes an actor is somewhere in the world
working on a project and they can't come in
for the audition, so they hold it over Skype.

Also, a lot of times they are auditioning
actors who are outside of the United States

and that is the most convenient way to hold
an audition.

All in all, the whole experience was really
cool, and I'm glad I could be part of it.

I hope to work with Skype again because it
was really neat to work with a brand that
I already love.
Who knows what will come up in the near future!

I will see you lovely people later and I promise
to have better hair next time.
